title: Before 1 April 2021, will an election be held for Israel's Knesset?
possible_answers: Yes, and Likud will win the most seats of any party
Yes, and Likud will tie or not win the most seats of any party
There will not be an election before 1 April 2021
correct_answer: Yes, and Likud will win the most seats of any party

Updating from 93/7/1 a little more towards Likud as the election is Sunday and all polling since Feb 2021 (when lists of candidates were finalized) have them at 27 or higher, and the next contender at 20 or lower. However, I don't know enough about Israeli politics to go more confident than this, so I will leave it as my final forecast.
In the end, the opposition is just too divided. All chips on Likud
Legislative elections will be held in Israel on Tuesday, 23 March 2021 to elect the 120 members of the 24th Knesset.

The Israeli government has scheduled an election of the new Knesset for 23 March 2021.  Over the last ten years, Likud has won more of the 120 seats than any other party in four of the five, with an average of 32.5 seats in each election.  Polls project Likud to win 28 seats in this election, a significant reduction in past support but still more seats than the other parties involved in this election.  Based on this, I believe there is an 85% chance Likud will win more seats than any other single party in this election and a 14% chance they will not.  I am leaving a 1% chance of terrorism causing the election to be postponed past 1 April 2021 because Middle East.

As things look now, polls have been pretty stable. Likud has been in the high 20s. Yesh Atid got 19 in the last poll vs. 28 for Likud, but unless something crazy happens like Benny Gantz with his 4 or so seats dropping out (sending most of those voters to YA presumably), it's hard to see how Likud fails to get a plurality, with a very high confidence at this point. I wish GJOpen would do a question on who wins the election -- would love to see the crowd's opinion.

Updating forecast of Jan 2nd (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1211893). Israel's coronavirus case numbers are coming down and less time's available for an event that would lead to postponement, so I'm lowering my estimate of such a postponement's likelihood to 2% (half the historical rate). Over the last week's polling, Likud's average estimated seat lead over its nearest opponent is now 13, around 7 times larger than the typical fortnightly change in the polling average since October. So with under four fortnights until the scheduled election, the probability of that seat lead falling sufficiently, under a Gaussian random walk, is less than 0.1%. Realistically, therefore, Likud will only fail to win most seats in an out-of-model scenario, such as a significant large-party merger (very unlikely, given the opposing parties' rhetoric and electoral incentives and the remaining time); a rapid, condemnatory, and poll-shifting decision against Netanyahu in his trial (rapidity and poll-shifting both being unlikely); or a major vaccine failure for which the government is blamed (extremely unlikely). I'll arbitrarily assign a 1% probability to each of those, leaving a 95% chance for Likud.

Elections have been scheduled and every poll shows Likud winning the most seats of any party. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Israeli_legislative_election) Unless there is a massive shift in public opinion, Likud will capture the most seats in the upcoming election.

Despite any possible hurdles Bibi may be facing, his parties holds more than twice the number of seats of the next, and given the proportional system of voting, for this to resolve in bucket 2, it would mean a loss of over 50% of Likud's base of the sudden consolidation of support around another leader during a pandemic.

Despite the Bibi fatigue, there just don't seem to be many scenarios where Likud fails to at least get a plurality. New Hope should do well, but what would put them over the top is their alliances with other parties, not necessarily because they themselves will garner the most votes.

First of all the thing which could postpone the election until after march is probably a surge in Covid19 cases in march which seems unlikely in face of Israels vaccination program. This program and its success is also the reason I am fairly confident that Likud will win the election. The biggest danger for Likud seems to be if the vaccination program fails because of supply problems or if the new South African strain of Covid19 is resistant to the virus and spreads in Israel. The other danger for Likud is the trial for Netanjahu which was recently postponed until February which could be positive for him if witness are only called after the election or negative if the witness are called during election week . Otherwise Likud has a 12 seat lead in the current polls which makes them likely to win the election  .

The law is worded in such a way that it has one loophole left, which concerns a situation in which the state budget is not approved, and it is this loophole that allowed Netanyahu to bring about a situation in which the Knesset dissolves and, despite this, the premiership does not pass to Gantz.

Given the speed at which Israel is vaccinating (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/01/world/middleeast/israel-coronavirus-vaccines.html), reducing the no election probability to 3%, and allocating it to Likud, also as time passes removing some of the 8% smoothing. Edit: I should add that I am not adjusting any numbers for Netanyahu's trial, as firstly it may be delayed again (https://www.timesofisrael.com/netanyahu-trial-may-face-further-delay-as-judges-hint-indictment-must-be-revised/), secondly supporters of populist leaders tend to ignore allegations of improprieties, so if they have supported him up until now, it is unlikely to change.

The election's scheduled for the 23rd March, with postponement only possible via a 2/3 majority in the Knesset, for special circumstances or proximity to a holiday (source https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/elections/.premium-how-israel-plans-to-pull-off-a-second-election-during-a-global-pandemic-1.9395162). Israel's postponed only one of its 23 scheduled legislative elections to date (in 1973, mentioned by @TheLopen and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Israel), but either the coronavirus crisis or Passover's effect on the vote count could be reason to do so. Israel currently has a large number of cases and no mail-in voting, but it's secured 8 million doses of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine and all high-risk groups are expected to be vaccinated by the end of February (https://www.businessinsider.com/how-israel-got-vaccines-to-its-citizens-under-2-weeks-2020-12?r=US&IR=T), so the 4% historical rate of postponement seems like a reasonable probability estimate in this case. If there is an election, Likud's the strong favourite to win the most seats. Israeli opinion polling's historically rather accurate (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2020_Israeli_legislative_election and its equivalents) and, over the last week of polling pulled from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Israeli_legislative_election, Likud's average estimated lead over its closest opponent is 10.5 seats. This is four times the standard deviation in that estimated seat lead over the last three months of polls so, even supposing volatility over the coming three months is twice as high, a normally distributed Likud seat lead would have a 2% chance of being less than 0.5. A fat-tailed distribution'll be more appropriate, some party consolidation's likely, and big news events will likely increase volatility (evidence in Netanyahu's trial, the vaccination process, ?), so I'll use a more conservative estimate of 90% for the probability of Likud winning most seats, conditioned on the election going ahead as scheduled.

The only occurrence of an election being delayed in Israeli history was during the Yom Kippur War. There is a low possibility of a similar conflict at the moment as Israel and many of its neighbors are opening new relations. Though the possibility of conflict with Syria and Iran is never out of the question, and the trial of Prime Minister Netanyahu (scheduled for just before the election in February) could cause a delay. Thus the 10% chance. March 2020

However, following the call for new elections last month 8 Blue and White legislators have left the party for various other parties or left politics all together. Current polling has them dropping below the 3.25% required to win seats. With the collapse of Blue and White it appears Likud will easily be the party with the most votes. Though there is a new offshoot of Likud called New Hope which is going to split the vote, currently new hope is polling at 17 seats while Likud is at 29. Though their odds appear good, the corruption trial against Likud leader Netanyahu will begin in February just as the campaigning is reaching its peak. The 20% chance of Likud not holding the most seats is for the possibility of Likud support collapsing if the trial were to go badly and Netanyahu was no longer able to run. https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/israel-heads-elections-nothing-different-everything-has-changed https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.timesofisrael.com/in-1st-election-poll-predicts-gantzs-blue-and-white-will-fail-to-enter-knesset/amp/ Election data is from Wikipedia

Elections are scheduled so I have no election as a very outside chance.  Using Wikipedia for opinion poll data - https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Israeli_legislative_election It feels like any poll based analysis would come up with a very high probability of Likud having the most seats. Backed up by relative accuracy in 2020 (https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2020_Israeli_legislative_election). I have not done a “model” here, but I reckon it would be in excess of 85%. Still a lot of time to go. PM’s trial cannot help matters, but the allegations have been out there so should be reflected in polls. Party combinations would be the other potential threat, but the system does not seem to create that much of an incentive to formally combine. Gone with 81% for Likud - will increase 3% a month if polls don’t move, for c. 90% if polls unchanged on the day before election

Likud will win the most seats, but is unlikely to gather a coalition large enough to govern. The anti-Netanyahu coalition is growing, and voter fatigue with a 4th election in 2 years is likely to cause problems for him. Although, on balance, his supporters tend to turn out more than others.

Israel's current govt structure is unsustainable. But Netanyahu has dominated for so long that there isn't really another viable candidate that he hasn't already poisoned. In addition, the ultra religious parties are so intent on getting everything they can that they'll make or break any govt to get their way.

Well that resolved quickly [1]. Looking at opinion polls [2] (conveniently available since the last election) we see that Likud has had at least a +3 seat advantage over the second most voted party the entire time since May 2020, and that advantage has widened to 6-12 since late Nov 2020. This suggests a 90+% chance for Likud. I looked at the previous election to see how long this pattern has lasted and was surprised to see that Blue and White had been a serious contender for most voted party [3], but now barely gets the half the votes it used to. It turns out that Blue and White split into two parties [4], and each is now getting roughly half the votes. This time around, New Hope is growing (although slowly), with a number of MKs from Likud joining it [2]. New Hope was founded by an influential politician after leaving Likud. A lot can happen in 3 months so I am knocking down the 90% to just 75%. [1] https://thehill.com/policy/international/middle-east-north-africa/531388-israeli-parliament-fails-to-pass-budget-setting
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2021_Israeli_legislative_election
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2020_Israeli_legislative_election
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_and_White_(political_alliance)

On the basis that the 120 seats in the Knesset are elected by closed list proportional representation in a single nationwide constituency, and that the last election was held only 9 months ago, the pollsters should be fairly accurate in their estimates at least in as far as they are predicting the largest party. Using the average of the Channel 12 and Kan polls (https://www.timesofisrael.com/as-knesset-to-dissolve-likud-leads-in-polls-but-no-clear-majority-for-netanyahu/) we have Likud at 28.5 seats and New Hope on 19 seats. The polls disagreed on the third party but agreed that it would only get around 15/16 votes. Unfortunately, there was no margin of error disclosed on the Kan poll but assuming it was similar to that of Channel 12 (4.2% or 5 seats), we get a probability of 97.5% of a Likud majority.  Allocating a 6% chance of the election being postponed from March 23rd for Covid/Political reasons, and smoothing the resultant Likud probability by 8% as it is early in the cycle, and we haven't had a lot of polls, I get an 84% chance of Likud.

Knesset has 120 members, 36 are likud (largest party).  This election there is a new party splintered from Likud called New Hope that may take a dozed votes from Likud. So this time around not so firm that Likud will be largest. Although maybe new hope takes the votes from Blue and White. I will adjust as polls come out
Elections will be held before 1 April since knesset desolved dec 22.  By law it has to be held March 23. I doubt Covid will stop it.
